[ChangeDelta, position: 482, lines: [            The win was the 14th and final win of Fittipaldi's career which had included two world championships. He would continue racing in Formula One until 1980. The win also vaulted Fittpaldi past ,             <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Reutemann" title="Carlos Reutemann">,               Carlos Reutemann] to [            Andretti had a long career in racing. He was the only person to be named United States Driver of the Year in three decades (1967, 1978, and 1984).,             <sup id="cite_ref-sportscentury_3-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-sportscentury-3">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 3,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              He was also one of only three drivers to win races on ,             <a href="/wiki/Road_racing" title="Road racing">,               road courses]]
[ChangeDelta, position: 486, lines: [             into second place in the championship, 14 points behind Lauda.] to [            , paved ,             <a href="/wiki/Oval_track" title="Oval track" class="mw-redirect">,               ovals,             </a>,             , and ,             <a href="/wiki/Dirt_track_racing" title="Dirt track racing">,               dirt tracks,             </a>,              in one season, a feat that he accomplished four times.,             <sup id="cite_ref-sportscentury_3-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-sportscentury-3">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 3,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              With his final IndyCar win in April 1993, Andretti became the first driver to win IndyCar races in four different decades,             <sup id="cite_ref-NYTimes04051993_4-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NYTimes04051993-4">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 4,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              and the first to win automobile races of any kind in five.,             <sup id="cite_ref-sportscentury_3-2" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-sportscentury-3">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 3,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>]]

[ChangeDelta, position: 584, lines: [             languishing on the fifth row.] to [            ).,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Istria was then a province of the ,             <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy_(1861%E2%80%931946)" title="Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)" class="mw-redirect">,               Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946),             </a>,             , but it was annexed by ,             <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">,               Yugoslavia,             </a>,              at the end of ,             <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">,               World War II,             </a>,             , as confirmed by the ,             <a href="/wiki/Paris_Peace_Treaties,_1947" title="Paris Peace Treaties, 1947">,               Treaty of Paris,             </a>,             . The Andretti family left Montona in 1948, during the ,             <a href="/wiki/Istrian_exodus" title="Istrian exodus">,               Istrian exodus,             </a>,             , ending up in a refugee camp in ,             <a href="/wiki/Lucca" title="Lucca">,               Lucca,             </a>,             , Italy.,             <sup id="cite_ref-Winer_7-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-Winer-7">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 7,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              They emigrated to the ,             <a href="/wiki/United_States_of_America" title="United States of America" class="mw-redirect">,               United States of America,             </a>,              in 1955, settling in ,             <a href="/wiki/Nazareth,_Pennsylvania" title="Nazareth, Pennsylvania">,               Nazareth,             </a>,              in ,             <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">,               Pennsylvania,             </a>,             's ,             <a href="/wiki/Lehigh_Valley" title="Lehigh Valley">,               Lehigh Valley,             </a>,              with just $125 to their name.,             <sup id="cite_ref-sportscentury_3-3" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-sportscentury-3">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 3,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Andretti became a ,             <a href="/wiki/Naturalization" title="Naturalization">,               naturalized,             </a>,              United States citizen in 1964.]]
[InsertDelta, position: 586, lines: [          <h2>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Racing_career">,               Racing career,             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Racing career">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h2>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Childhood_involvement_in_motorsports">,               Childhood involvement in motorsports,             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Childhood involvement in motorsports">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h3>]]
[ChangeDelta, position: 587, lines: [            <a href="/wiki/Graham_Hill" title="Graham Hill">,               Graham Hill] to [            The twins' mother Rina said that when they were two years old, they would take pot lids out of the cupboards and run around the kitchen, going "Vroom, vroom," like they were driving cars – this before they had seen a car.,             <sup id="cite_ref-sportscentury_3-4" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-sportscentury-3">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 3,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              In 1945, at the age of five, he and Aldo were racing their hand-crafted wooden cars through the steep streets of their hometown.,             <sup id="cite_ref-milwaukee_8-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-milwaukee-8">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 8,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Later, the brothers were hired by a garage to park cars, Andretti described the experience in his book ,             <i>,               What's It Like Out There,             </i>,             : "The first time I fired up a car, felt the engine shudder and the wheel come to life in my hands, I was hooked. It was a feeling I can't describe. I still get it every time I get into a race car.",             <sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-9">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 9,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Andretti's first racing experience was in a new youth racing league called Formula Junior in ,             <a href="/wiki/Ancona,_Italy" title="Ancona, Italy" class="mw-redirect">,               Ancona, Italy]]
[ChangeDelta, position: 590, lines: [             announced his retirement as a driver after 17 seasons and 176 races to concentrate on his ,             <a href="/wiki/Embassy_Hill" title="Embassy Hill">,               Embassy Hill] to [             when he was thirteen years old.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-texaco_10-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-texaco-10">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 10,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              He had two fond childhood memories of watching a stretch of the ,             <a href="/wiki/Mille_Miglia" title="Mille Miglia">,               Mille Miglia]]
[ChangeDelta, position: 594, lines: [             team.] to [             race in 1954 which caused him to become captivated by Italian two-time Formula One world champion ,             <a href="/wiki/Alberto_Ascari" title="Alberto Ascari">,               Alberto Ascari,             </a>,             , who won the race, which got him to go to ,             <a href="/wiki/Autodromo_Nazionale_Monza" title="Autodromo Nazionale Monza">,               Monza,             </a>,              for the ,             <a href="/wiki/1954_Italian_Grand_Prix" title="1954 Italian Grand Prix">,               Italian Grand Prix,             </a>,             , where he saw Ascari and ,             <a href="/wiki/Juan_Manuel_Fangio" title="Juan Manuel Fangio">,               Juan Manuel Fangio,             </a>,              race against each other.,             <sup id="cite_ref-texaco_10-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-texaco-10">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 10,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-mshf_11-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-mshf-11">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 11,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>]]

[ChangeDelta, position: 597, lines: [            From the start – in which a lights system was being used for the first time in any Grand Prix, replacing the traditional national flag – ,             <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Pace" title="Carlos Pace">,               Carlos Pace] to [            Mario and Aldo were surprised to find a half-mile dirt racing track when they moved to Nazareth.,             <sup id="cite_ref-sportscentury_3-5" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-sportscentury-3">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 3,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The twins worked on a 1948 ,             <a href="/wiki/Hudson_Hornet" title="Hudson Hornet">,               Hudson Hornet]]
[ChangeDelta, position: 601, lines: [             led from Pryce.] to [             Sportsman ,             <a href="/wiki/Modified_stock_car_racing" title="Modified stock car racing">,               modified,             </a>,              funded by money that they earned in their uncle's garage in 1959.,             <sup id="cite_ref-sportscentury_3-6" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-sportscentury-3">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 3,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              They took turns racing the old ,             <a href="/wiki/Hudson_Motor_Car" title="Hudson Motor Car" class="mw-redirect">,               Hudson,             </a>,              on oval ,             <a href="/wiki/Dirt_track_racing" title="Dirt track racing">,               dirt tracks,             </a>,              near Nazareth in 1959. They did not tell their parents that they were racing.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-2" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The twins each had two wins after their first four races.,             <sup id="cite_ref-ESPN_12-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-ESPN-12">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 12,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Aldo was seriously hurt near the end of the season, and their parents were unhappy to find out that the twins were racing.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-3" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Mario had 21 modified stockcar wins in 46 races in 1960 and 1961.,             <sup id="cite_ref-sportscentury_3-7" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-sportscentury-3">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 3,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>]]

[ChangeDelta, position: 604, lines: [            Following the hail storm, only five cars were running at the end. The RAC declared the race finished officially on the lap after the lap when most cars were running – lap 56. ] to [            Andretti occasionally competed in ,             <a href="/wiki/United_States_Automobile_Club" title="United States Automobile Club" class="mw-redirect">,               United States Automobile Club,             </a>,              (USAC) stock car events. He competed in USAC stock cars in 1965, and finished twelfth in the season points.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-4" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              He won a USAC Stock Car race in 1967, and finished seventh in the season points.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-5" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              He won three 1974 USAC stock car races on road courses, and won four road course races in 1975.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-6" class="reference">,               <a font-size: larger"/>,                       </tr>,                     </tbody>,                   </table>,                 </td>,               </tr>,             </tbody>,           </table>,           <p>,             Andretti competed in fourteen ,             <a href="/wiki/NASCAR" title="NASCAR">,               NASCAR,             </a>,              Grand National/Winston Cup (now ,             <a href="/wiki/Sprint_Cup_Series" title="Sprint Cup Series">,               Sprint Cup,             </a>,             ) events in his career. He competed in ,             <a href="/wiki/Holman_Moody" title="Holman Moody">,               Holman Moody,             </a>,              cars for his final ten events. Holman Moody was one of NASCAR's most successful teams at that time, as the team won NASCAR championships in 1968 and 1969 with driver ,             <a href="/wiki/David_Pearson_(NASCAR_driver)" title="David Pearson (NASCAR driver)" class="mw-redirect">,               David Pearson,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-13">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 13,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Andretti won the ,             <a href="/wiki/1967_Daytona_500" title="1967 Daytona 500">,               1967 Daytona 500,             </a>,              for ,             <a href="/wiki/Holman_Moody" title="Holman Moody">,               Holman Moody,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-racing-reference_14-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-racing-reference-14">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 14,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <h4>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="International_Race_of_Champions">,               International Race of Champions,             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: International Race of Champions">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h4>,           <p>,             Andretti was invited to race in six ,             <a href="/wiki/International_Race_of_Champions" title="International Race of Champions">,               International Race of Champions,             </a>,              (IROC) series in his career. His best years were his first three years. He finished second in the final points standings in ,             <a href="/wiki/IROC_III" title="IROC III">,               IROC III,             </a>,              (1975–1976) and ,             <a href="/wiki/IROC_V" title="IROC V">,               IROC V,             </a>,              (1977–1978). He won the ,             <a href="/wiki/IROC_VI" title="IROC VI">,               IROC VI,             </a>,              (1978–1979) points championship with finishes of third, first, and second. He won three races in twenty events.,             <sup id="cite_ref-racing-reference_14-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-racing-reference-14">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 14,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Open_wheel_racing">,               Open wheel racing,             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Open wheel racing">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h3>,           <h4>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Early_open_wheel_racing">,               Early open wheel racing,             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Early open wheel racing">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h4>,           <p>,             Andretti's goal was to race in single-seater ,             <a href="/wiki/Open_wheel_racing" title="Open wheel racing" class="mw-redirect">,               open wheel,             </a>,              cars. Andretti said "Aldo and I were winning in the modifieds. But my objective was to get into open-wheelers.",             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-7" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Andretti raced ,             <a href="/wiki/Midget_car_racing" title="Midget car racing">,               midget cars,             </a>,              from 1961 to 1963. He started racing 3/4 (sized) ,             <a href="/wiki/Midget_car_racing" title="Midget car racing">,               midget cars,             </a>,              in the American Three Quarter Midget Racing Association in the winter to be seen by full-sized midget car owners.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-8" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              He raced in over one hundred events in 1963.,             <sup id="cite_ref-8W_15-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-8W-15">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 15,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Andretti won three feature races at two different tracks on ,             <a href="/wiki/Labor_Day_(United_States)" title="Labor Day (United States)" class="mw-redirect">,               Labor Day,             </a>,              in 1963.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-9" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              He won an afternoon feature at ,             <a href="/wiki/Flemington,_New_Jersey" title="Flemington, New Jersey">,               Flemington, New Jersey,             </a>,             , and swept twin features at ,             <a href="/wiki/Hatfield,_Pennsylvania" title="Hatfield, Pennsylvania">,               Hatfield, Pennsylvania,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-10" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             The next rung on the racing ladder on the ,             <a href="/wiki/East_Coast_of_the_United_States" title="East Coast of the United States">,               East Coast of the United States,             </a>,              was to race in ,             <a href="/wiki/Sprint_car_racing" title="Sprint car racing">,               sprint cars,             </a>,              in the ,             <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Racing_Club&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Racing Club (page does not exist)">,               United Racing Club,             </a>,              (URC).,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-11" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Andretti was able to get a ride for individual races in the URC sprint car racing series, but was unable to secure a full-time ride.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-12" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              He once drove from ,             <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">,               Canada,             </a>,              to ,             <a href="/wiki/Mechanicsburg,_Pennsylvania" title="Mechanicsburg, Pennsylvania">,               Mechanicsburg, Pennsylvania,             </a>,              hoping to find a ride in an event, but he went empty-handed. He bypassed the series when he was offered a full-time ride in a ,             <a href="/wiki/United_States_Automobile_Club" title="United States Automobile Club" class="mw-redirect">,               United States Automobile Club,             </a>,             <a href="/wiki/Sprint_car_racing" title="Sprint car racing">,               sprint car,             </a>,              for 1964.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-13" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <h4>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="USAC_sprint_cars">,               USAC sprint cars,             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: USAC sprint cars">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h4>,           <p>,             Andretti won the 1964 Joe James-Pat O'Connor Memorial USAC sprint car race at ,             <a href="/wiki/Salem_Speedway" title="Salem Speedway">,               Salem Speedway,             </a>,              in ,             <a href="/wiki/Salem,_Indiana" title="Salem, Indiana">,               Salem, Indiana,             </a>,             . Andretti continued to race in USAC sprint cars after moving into champ cars. In 1965 he won once at ,             <a href="/wiki/Ascot_Park_(speedway)" title="Ascot Park (speedway)">,               Ascot Park,             </a>,             , and finished tenth in the season points.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-14" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              In 1966 he won five times (,             <a href="/wiki/Cumberland,_Maryland" title="Cumberland, Maryland">,               Cumberland, Maryland,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Oswego,_New_York" title="Oswego, New York">,               Oswego, New York,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Rossburg,_Ohio" title="Rossburg, Ohio">,               Rossburg, Ohio,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Phoenix,_Arizona" title="Phoenix, Arizona">,               Phoenix, Arizona,             </a>,             , and his second win at the Joe James-Pat O'Connor Memorial at ,             <a href="/wiki/Salem_Speedway" title="Salem Speedway">,               Salem Speedway,             </a>,             ), but finished behind ,             <a href="/wiki/Roger_McCluskey" title="Roger McCluskey">,               Roger McCluskey,             </a>,              in the season championship.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-15" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              In 1967 he won two of the three events that he entered.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-16" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <h4>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="IndyCar_career_.281964-1974.29">,               IndyCar career (1964-1974),             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: IndyCar career (1964-1974)">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h4>,           <p>,             From 1956 to 1979, the top ,             <a href="/wiki/Open_wheel_racing" title="Open wheel racing" class="mw-redirect">,               open wheel racing,             </a>,              series in North America was the USAC National Championship. It was often referred to as ,             <a href="/wiki/Champ_car" title="Champ car" class="mw-redirect">,               Champ car,             </a>,              racing, or Indycar racing, referring to the famous ,             <a href="/wiki/Indianapolis_500" title="Indianapolis 500">,               Indianapolis 500,             </a>,              race which was the centerpiece of the championship. The races were run on a mixture of paved and dirt ovals, and in later years also included some road courses.,           </p>,           <p>,             Andretti made his Champ Car debut on April 19, 1964 at the New Jersey State fairgrounds in ,             <a href="/wiki/Trenton,_New_Jersey" title="Trenton, New Jersey">,               Trenton, New Jersey,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-17" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              He started sixteenth and finishing eleventh. Andretti was introduced by his USAC sprint car owner, Rufus Gray, to veteran mechanic Clint Brawner. Brawner was not impressed since sprint car drivers Stan Bowman and Donnie Davis had recently died, and Brawner's current driver, ,             <a href="/wiki/Chuck_Hulse" title="Chuck Hulse">,               Chuck Hulse,             </a>,             , had been critically injured.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-18" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <a href="/wiki/Chris_Economaki" title="Chris Economaki">,               Chris Economaki,             </a>,              recommended Andretti to Brawner, so Brawner watched Andretti race at ,             <a href="/wiki/Terre_Haute,_Indiana" title="Terre Haute, Indiana">,               Terre Haute, Indiana,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-19" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Brawner was convinced that he had found the new driver for his team.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-20" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The two stayed together for six years.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-21" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Andretti finished eleventh in the USAC National Championship that season.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-22" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Andretti won his first championship car race at the Hoosier Grand Prix on a road course at ,             <a href="/wiki/Indianapolis_Raceway_Park" title="Indianapolis Raceway Park" class="mw-redirect">,               Indianapolis Raceway Park,             </a>,              in 1965.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-23" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              His third place finish at the ,             <a href="/wiki/1965_Indianapolis_500" title="1965 Indianapolis 500">,               1965 Indianapolis 500,             </a>,              in the Brawner Hawk (a mechanical copy of the current Brabham Formula 1 design) earned him the race's ,             <a href="/wiki/List_of_Indianapolis_500_Rookies_of_the_Year" title="List of Indianapolis 500 Rookies of the Year" class="mw-redirect">,               Rookie of the Year,             </a>,              award, and contributed towards Andretti winning the series championship. He was the youngest national champion in series history at age 25.,             <sup id="cite_ref-8W_15-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-8W-15">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 15,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              He repeated as series champion in 1966,,             <sup id="cite_ref-texaco_10-2" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-texaco-10">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 10,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              winning eight of fifteen events.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-24" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              He also won the pole at the ,             <a href="/wiki/1966_Indianapolis_500" title="1966 Indianapolis 500">,               1966 Indianapolis 500,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-25" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Andretti finished second in the IndyCars in 1967 and 1968. He also won a single non-championship ,             <a href="/wiki/Drag_racing" title="Drag racing">,               drag race,             </a>,              in 1967 in a ,             <a href="/wiki/Ford_Mustang" title="Ford Mustang">,               Ford Mustang,             </a>,             . In both 1967 and 1968, Andretti lost the season USAC championship to ,             <a href="/wiki/A.J._Foyt" title="A.J. Foyt" class="mw-redirect">,               A.J. Foyt,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Bobby_Unser" title="Bobby Unser">,               Bobby Unser,             </a>,             , respectively, in the waning laps of the last race of the season at Riverside, California—each by the smallest points margin in history.,           </p>,           <div class="thumb tleft">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:AndrettiHawk.jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/AndrettiHawk.jpg/220px-AndrettiHawk.jpg" width="220" height="126" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/AndrettiHawk.jpg/330px-AndrettiHawk.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/AndrettiHawk.jpg/440px-AndrettiHawk.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1464"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:AndrettiHawk.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 , A replica of the Brawner Hawk in which Andretti won the 1969 Indy 500 resides in the ,                 <a href="/wiki/Indianapolis_Motor_Speedway_Hall_of_Fame_Museum" title="Indianapolis Motor Speedway Hall of Fame Museum">,                   Indianapolis Motor Speedway Hall of Fame Museum,                 </a>,                 .,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             Andretti won nine races in 1969, the ,             <a href="/wiki/1969_Indianapolis_500" title="1969 Indianapolis 500">,               1969 Indianapolis 500,             </a>,             , and the season championship. He also won the ,             <a href="/wiki/Pikes_Peak_International_Hill_Climb" title="Pikes Peak International Hill Climb">,               Pikes Peak International Hill Climb,             </a>,             , which was part of the USAC National Championship.,             <sup id="cite_ref-ESPN_12-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-ESPN-12">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 12,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              He was named ,             <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">,               ABC,             </a>,             's ,             <a href="/wiki/Wide_World_of_Sports_(U.S._TV_series)" title="Wide World of Sports (U.S. TV series)">,               Wide World of Sports,             </a>,              Athlete of the Year. Between 1966 and 1969 he won 29 of 85 USAC championship races.,             <sup id="cite_ref-sportscentury_3-8" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-sportscentury-3">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 3,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             In 1973, USAC split its National Championship into dirt and pavement championships.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-26" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Andretti had one win on the pavement and finished fifth in the season points, and finished second in the dirt championship.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-27" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              He competed in USAC's dirt track division in 1974, and won the dirt track championship while competing in both series.,             <sup id="cite_ref-sportscentury_3-9" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-sportscentury-3">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 3,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Andretti also competed in the North American ,             <a href="/wiki/Formula_5000" title="Formula 5000">,               Formula 5000,             </a>,              series in 1973 and 1974, and finished second in the championship in both seasons.,             <sup id="cite_ref-sportscentury_3-10" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-sportscentury-3">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 3,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <h4>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Formula_One_career">,               Formula One career,             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Formula One career">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h4>,           <h5>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Part-time_status_.281968-1972.2C_1974.29">,               Part-time status (1968-1972, 1974),             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Part-time status (1968-1972, 1974)">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h5>,           <div class="thumb tleft">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:AndrettiMario19690801Lotus63-Allrad-3.jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/AndrettiMario19690801Lotus63-Allrad-3.jpg/220px-AndrettiMario19690801Lotus63-Allrad-3.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/AndrettiMario19690801Lotus63-Allrad-3.jpg/330px-AndrettiMario19690801Lotus63-Allrad-3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/AndrettiMario19690801Lotus63-Allrad-3.jpg/440px-AndrettiMario19690801Lotus63-Allrad-3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="769"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:AndrettiMario19690801Lotus63-Allrad-3.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 , Andretti drove his ,                 <a href="/wiki/Team_Lotus" title="Team Lotus">,                   Lotus,                 </a>,                 <a href="/wiki/Lotus_63" title="Lotus 63">,                   Type 63,                 </a>,                  at the ,                 <a href="/wiki/1969_German_Grand_Prix" title="1969 German Grand Prix">,                   1969 German Grand Prix,                 </a>,                 .,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <div class="thumb tleft">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:Lotus_77_Sears_Point.jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Lotus_77_Sears_Point.jpg/220px-Lotus_77_Sears_Point.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Lotus_77_Sears_Point.jpg/330px-Lotus_77_Sears_Point.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Lotus_77_Sears_Point.jpg/440px-Lotus_77_Sears_Point.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Lotus_77_Sears_Point.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 , Andretti's ,                 <a href="/wiki/Lotus_77" title="Lotus 77">,                   Lotus 77,                 </a>,                  racecar,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">,               Formula One,             </a>,              is the highest form of open wheel racing sanctioned by the ,             <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A9d%C3%A9ration_Internationale_de_l%27Automobile" title="Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile">,               Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile,             </a>,              (FIA), motorsport's international governing body. Although originating in Europe, by the 1960s it included races worldwide. At Andretti's first Indianapolis 500, in 1965, he met ,             <a href="/wiki/Colin_Chapman" title="Colin Chapman">,               Colin Chapman,             </a>,             , owner of the ,             <a href="/wiki/Team_Lotus" title="Team Lotus">,               Lotus,             </a>,              Formula One team, who was running eventual race winner ,             <a href="/wiki/Jim_Clark" title="Jim Clark">,               Jim Clark,             </a>,             's car.,             <sup id="cite_ref-FormulaOne.com_16-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-FormulaOne.com-16">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 16,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Andretti told Chapman of his ambition to compete in Formula One and was told "When you're ready, call me.",             <sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-17">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 17,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              By 1968 Andretti felt he was ready. Chapman gave him a car, and the young American took the pole position on his debut at the ,             <a href="/wiki/1968_United_States_Grand_Prix" title="1968 United States Grand Prix">,               1968 United States Grand Prix,             </a>,              at ,             <a href="/wiki/Watkins_Glen_International" title="Watkins Glen International">,               Watkins Glen,             </a>,              in his ,             <a href="/wiki/Lotus_49" title="Lotus 49">,               Lotus 49,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-FormulaOne.com_16-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-FormulaOne.com-16">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 16,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-18">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 18,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Andretti drove sporadically in Formula One over the next four years for Lotus, ,             <a href="/wiki/March_Engineering" title="March Engineering">,               March,             </a>,             , and ]]
[ChangeDelta, position: 608, lines: [            , with both of their cars stuck on lap 54 in the classification protested, but the RAC threw these protests out and three days later, the provisional results were confirmed.] to [            , while continuing to focus on his racing career in America.,             <sup id="cite_ref-FormulaOne.com_16-2" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-FormulaOne.com-16">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 16,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              At the ,             <a href="/wiki/1971_South_African_Grand_Prix" title="1971 South African Grand Prix">,               1971 South African Grand Prix,             </a>,             , on his debut for Ferrari, he won his first Grand Prix.,             <sup id="cite_ref-FormulaOne.com_16-3" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-FormulaOne.com-16">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 16,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Three weeks later, at the non-championship Questor Grand Prix in the U.S., he brought the Italian team a second victory.,             <sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-19">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 19,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>]]
[InsertDelta, position: 610, lines: [          <h5>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Full-time_status_.281975-1981.29">,               Full-time status (1975-1981),             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Full-time status (1975-1981)">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h5>,           <p>,             It wasn't until ,             <a href="/wiki/1975_Formula_One_season" title="1975 Formula One season">,               1975,             </a>,              that Andretti drove a full Formula One season, for the American ,             <a href="/wiki/Parnelli" title="Parnelli" class="mw-redirect">,               Parnelli,             </a>,              team. The team was new to Formula One, although it had been successful in both ,             <a href="/wiki/Formula_5000" title="Formula 5000">,               Formula 5000,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Championship_Car" title="Championship Car" class="mw-redirect">,               IndyCar,             </a>,              racing in America with Andretti driving. The team had run Andretti in the two North American end-of-season races in 1974 with promising results. Andretti qualified fourth and led the ,             <a href="/wiki/1975_Spanish_Grand_Prix" title="1975 Spanish Grand Prix">,               1975 Spanish Grand Prix,             </a>,              for nine laps before his suspension failed. He scored five championship points in the season. Andretti continued to compete in IndyCar, missing two Formula One races in the middle of the season to do so.,             <sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-20">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 20,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <div class="thumb tleft">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:Andretti_celebrating_at_1978_Dutch_Grand_Prix.jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Andretti_celebrating_at_1978_Dutch_Grand_Prix.jpg/250px-Andretti_celebrating_at_1978_Dutch_Grand_Prix.jpg" width="250" height="166" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Andretti_celebrating_at_1978_Dutch_Grand_Prix.jpg/375px-Andretti_celebrating_at_1978_Dutch_Grand_Prix.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Andretti_celebrating_at_1978_Dutch_Grand_Prix.jpg/500px-Andretti_celebrating_at_1978_Dutch_Grand_Prix.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="848"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Andretti_celebrating_at_1978_Dutch_Grand_Prix.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 , Andretti celebrating victory in 1978,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             When the Parnelli team pulled out of Formula One after two races of the ,             <a href="/wiki/1976_Formula_One_season" title="1976 Formula One season">,               1976 season,             </a>,             , Andretti returned to Chapman's Lotus team, for whom he had already driven at the season-opening ,             <a href="/wiki/1976_Brazilian_Grand_Prix" title="1976 Brazilian Grand Prix">,               Brazilian Grand Prix,             </a>,             . Lotus was then at a low point, having failed to produce a competitive car to replace 1970's ,             <a href="/wiki/Lotus_72" title="Lotus 72">,               Lotus 72,             </a>,             . Andretti's ability at developing a racing car contributed to Lotus' return to the front of the Formula One grid, culminating in lapping the field in his victory at the season ending race at the ,             <a href="/wiki/Fuji_Speedway" title="Fuji Speedway">,               Mount Fuji,             </a>,              circuit in Japan.,             <sup id="cite_ref-FormulaOne.com_16-4" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-FormulaOne.com-16">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 16,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Since mid-1975 Lotus had been developing the use of ,             <a href="/wiki/Ground_effect_(cars)" title="Ground effect (cars)">,               ground effect,             </a>,             , shaping the underside of the car to generate ,             <a href="/wiki/Downforce" title="Downforce">,               downforce,             </a>,              with little penalizing ,             <a href="/wiki/Drag_(physics)" title="Drag (physics)">,               drag,             </a>,             . For his part, Andretti worked at setting up his cars for the races, exploiting subtle differences in tire size ('stagger') and suspension set up ('cross weighting') on each side of the car to optimize it for each track, an approach imported from his extensive oval racing experience in the United States.,             <sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-21">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 21,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              In 1977, at ,             <a href="/wiki/Long_Beach,_California" title="Long Beach, California">,               Long Beach,             </a>,             , he became the only American to win the ,             <a href="/wiki/United_States_Grand_Prix_West" title="United States Grand Prix West">,               United States Grand Prix West,             </a>,             , and the last American as of 2013 to win any US Grand Prix.,             <sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-22">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 22,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The ,             <a href="/wiki/Lotus_78" title="Lotus 78">,               Lotus 78,             </a>,              "wing car" proved to be the most competitive car of 1977,,             <sup id="cite_ref-ddavid_23-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-ddavid-23">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 23,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              but despite winning four races, more than any other driver, reliability problems and collisions with other drivers meant Andretti finished only third in the championship.,             <sup id="cite_ref-ddavid_23-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-ddavid-23">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 23,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The following year, the ,             <a href="/wiki/Lotus_79" title="Lotus 79">,               Lotus 79,             </a>,              exploited ground effect even further and Andretti took the title with six wins.,             <sup id="cite_ref-ddavid_23-2" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-ddavid-23">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 23,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              He clinched the championship at the ,             <a href="/wiki/1978_Italian_Grand_Prix" title="1978 Italian Grand Prix">,               Italian Grand Prix,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-sportscentury_3-11" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-sportscentury-3">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 3,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              There was no championship celebration because his teammate and close friend ,             <a href="/wiki/Ronnie_Peterson" title="Ronnie Peterson">,               Ronnie Peterson,             </a>,              crashed heavily at the start of the race; he was hospitalised and died that night from complications resulting from his injuries.,             <sup id="cite_ref-sportscentury_3-12" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-sportscentury-3">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 3,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Andretti would find little success after 1978 in Formula One – he failed to win another grand prix. He had a difficult year in 1979, as the new ,             <a href="/wiki/Lotus_80" title="Lotus 80">,               Lotus 80,             </a>,              was not competitive, and the team had to rely on the Lotus 79 which had been overtaken by the second generation of ground effect cars.,             <sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-24">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 24,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              In 1980, he was paired with the young Italian ,             <a href="/wiki/Elio_de_Angelis" title="Elio de Angelis">,               Elio de Angelis,             </a>,             , and briefly with test driver ,             <a href="/wiki/Nigel_Mansell" title="Nigel Mansell">,               Nigel Mansell,             </a>,             , but the team was again unsuccessful.,             <sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-25">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 25,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <div class="thumb tleft">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:Andretti_at_1981_Dutch_Grand_Prix.jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Andretti_at_1981_Dutch_Grand_Prix.jpg/250px-Andretti_at_1981_Dutch_Grand_Prix.jpg" width="250" height="166" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Andretti_at_1981_Dutch_Grand_Prix.jpg/375px-Andretti_at_1981_Dutch_Grand_Prix.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Andretti_at_1981_Dutch_Grand_Prix.jpg/500px-Andretti_at_1981_Dutch_Grand_Prix.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="851"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Andretti_at_1981_Dutch_Grand_Prix.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 , Andretti driving the Alfa Romeo 179C at the Dutch Grand Prix in 1981,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             Andretti had an unsuccessful ,             <a href="/wiki/1981_Formula_One_season" title="1981 Formula One season">,               1981,             </a>,              with the ,             <a href="/wiki/Alfa_Romeo_(Formula_One)" title="Alfa Romeo (Formula One)" class="mw-redirect">,               Alfa Romeo,             </a>,              team. Like other drivers of the period he did not like the ground effect cars of the time: "the cars were getting absurd, really crude, with no suspension movement whatever. It was toggle switch driving with no need for any kind of delicacy...it made leaving Formula One a lot easier than it would have been.",             <sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-26">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 26,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <h5>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Brief_returns_with_Williams_and_Ferrari_.281982.29">,               Brief returns with Williams and Ferrari (1982),             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Brief returns with Williams and Ferrari (1982)">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h5>,           <p>,             The next year Andretti raced once for the ,             <a href="/wiki/Williams_F1" title="Williams F1" class="mw-redirect">,               Williams,             </a>,              team, after their driver ,             <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Reutemann" title="Carlos Reutemann">,               Carlos Reutemann,             </a>,              suddenly quit, before replacing the seriously injured ,             <a href="/wiki/Didier_Pironi" title="Didier Pironi">,               Didier Pironi,             </a>,              at Ferrari for the last two races of the year. Suspension failure dropped him out of the last race of the season, but at the Italian Grand Prix at Monza he took the pole position and finished third in the race.,             <sup id="cite_ref-FormulaOne.com_16-5" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-FormulaOne.com-16">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 16,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-27">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 27,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             In a 2012 interview, ,             <a href="/wiki/1980_Formula_One_season" title="1980 Formula One season">,               1980,             </a>,              World Champion ,             <a href="/wiki/Alan_Jones_(racing_driver)" title="Alan Jones (racing driver)">,               Alan Jones,             </a>,              stated that Ferrari, looking for a proven top class driver, had actually contacted him to drive for the team in late 1982. Jones however was enjoying his time back in ,             <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">,               Australia,             </a>,              and took too long to give Ferrari an answer (a move Jones regrets) so instead they contacted Andretti who had no such hesitations. Ironically, Jones later decided to make a comeback to F1 in 1983 (unlike Andretti) and had he taken the seat at Ferrari its likely they would have kept the former World Champion for that year which would have seen him drive a very competitive car (Ferrari won the Constructors' Championship in 1983).,           </p>,           <p>,             There was almost a return to F1 for Andretti at the ,             <a href="/wiki/1984_Detroit_Grand_Prix" title="1984 Detroit Grand Prix">,               1984 Detroit Grand Prix,             </a>,              when he was put on stand by the ,             <a href="/wiki/Renault_F1" title="Renault F1" class="mw-redirect">,               Renault,             </a>,              team to replace regular driver ,             <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Tambay" title="Patrick Tambay">,               Patrick Tambay,             </a>,              if the Frenchman had been unable to race, as was the case at the previous race in ,             <a href="/wiki/1984_Canadian_Grand_Prix" title="1984 Canadian Grand Prix">,               Canada,             </a>,             . However, in the event, Tambay was able to take part in the race.,             <sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-28">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 28,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Andretti was also considered as a replacement, again for Tambay who had been injured in ,             <a href="/wiki/1986_Canadian_Grand_Prix" title="1986 Canadian Grand Prix">,               Canada,             </a>,             , at the ,             <a href="/wiki/1986_Detroit_Grand_Prix" title="1986 Detroit Grand Prix">,               1986 Detroit Grand Prix,             </a>,             , this time for the Carl Haas owned Haas Lola team. Mario declined however, but recommended his son Michael Andretti for the drive. Unfortunately for Michael he was unable to obtain the FIA ,             <a href="/wiki/Superlicense" title="Superlicense" class="mw-redirect">,               Superlicense,             </a>,              required to allow him to race in Formula One. Instead the drive went to ,             <a href="/wiki/Eddie_Cheever" title="Eddie Cheever">,               Eddie Cheever,             </a>,             .,           </p>,           <h4>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Return_to_IndyCar_racing_.281982-1994.29">,               Return to IndyCar racing (1982-1994),             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Return to IndyCar racing (1982-1994)">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h4>,           <div class="thumb tright">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:Mario_Andretti_1991_Laguna_Seca.jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Mario_Andretti_1991_Laguna_Seca.jpg/220px-Mario_Andretti_1991_Laguna_Seca.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Mario_Andretti_1991_Laguna_Seca.jpg/330px-Mario_Andretti_1991_Laguna_Seca.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Mario_Andretti_1991_Laguna_Seca.jpg/440px-Mario_Andretti_1991_Laguna_Seca.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="853"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Mario_Andretti_1991_Laguna_Seca.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 , Andretti driving at ,                 <a href="/wiki/Laguna_Seca_Raceway" title="Laguna Seca Raceway" class="mw-redirect">,                   Laguna Seca Raceway,                 </a>,                  in 1991.,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             Andretti had continued to race, and occasionally win, in the USAC National Championship during his time in the Formula One world championship. In 1979 a new organization, ,             <a href="/wiki/Championship_Auto_Racing_Teams" title="Championship Auto Racing Teams" class="mw-redirect">,               Championship Auto Racing Teams,             </a>,             , had set up the Indycar world series as a rival to the USAC National Championships that Andretti had won three times in the 1960s. The new series had rapidly become the top open wheel racing series in North America.,             <sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-29">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 29,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             It was to this arena that Andretti returned full-time in 1982, driving for ,             <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Racing" title="Patrick Racing">,               Patrick Racing,             </a>,             . In 1983 he joined the new ,             <a href="/wiki/Newman/Haas_Racing" title="Newman/Haas Racing">,               Newman/Haas Racing,             </a>,              team, set up by ,             <a href="/wiki/Carl_Haas" title="Carl Haas">,               Carl Haas,             </a>,              and actor ,             <a href="/wiki/Paul_Newman" title="Paul Newman">,               Paul Newman,             </a>,              using cars built by British company ,             <a href="/wiki/Lola_Cars" title="Lola Cars">,               Lola,             </a>,             . Andretti took the team's first win at ,             <a href="/wiki/Road_America" title="Road America">,               Elkhart Lake,             </a>,              in ,             <a href="/wiki/1983_IndyCar_season" title="1983 IndyCar season">,               1983,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-30">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 30,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              He won the pole for nine of sixteen events in ,             <a href="/wiki/1984_IndyCar_season" title="1984 IndyCar season">,               1984,             </a>,             , and claimed his fourth ,             <a href="/wiki/American_Championship_Car_Racing" title="American Championship Car Racing" class="mw-redirect">,               Champ Car,             </a>,              title at the age of 44. He edged out ,             <a href="/wiki/Tom_Sneva" title="Tom Sneva">,               Tom Sneva,             </a>,              by 13 points. It was the first series title for the second year team.,           </p>,           <div class="thumb tleft">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:Mario_Andretti_1984.jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Mario_Andretti_1984.jpg/220px-Mario_Andretti_1984.jpg" width="220" height="291" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Mario_Andretti_1984.jpg/330px-Mario_Andretti_1984.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/df/Mario_Andretti_1984.jpg 2x" data-file-width="358" data-file-height="474"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Mario_Andretti_1984.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 , Andretti in 1984,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             Mario's son ,             <a href="/wiki/Michael_Andretti" title="Michael Andretti">,               Michael,             </a>,              joined Newman/Haas in 1989. Together, they made history as the first father/son team to compete in both ,             <a href="/wiki/IMSA_GT_Championship" title="IMSA GT Championship">,               IMSA GT,             </a>,              and Champ Car racing,,             <sup id="cite_ref-texaco_10-3" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-texaco-10">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 10,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              as for the former, it was their fourth time in an endurance race together as co-drivers. Mario finished seventh in points for the 1991 season, the year that Michael won the championship. Mario's last victory in IndyCar racing came in 1993 at ,             <a href="/wiki/Phoenix_International_Raceway" title="Phoenix International Raceway">,               Phoenix International Raceway,             </a>,             ,,             <sup id="cite_ref-NYTimes04051993_4-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NYTimes04051993-4">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 4,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              the year that Michael left Newman/Haas to race in Formula One. The win made Mario the oldest recorded winner in an IndyCar event (53 years, 34 days old).,             <sup id="cite_ref-NYTimes04051993_4-2" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NYTimes04051993-4">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 4,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-31">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 31,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Andretti qualified on the pole at the ,             <a href="/wiki/Michigan_500" title="Michigan 500" class="mw-redirect">,               Michigan 500,             </a>,              later that year with a speed of 234.275 miles per hour (377.029 km/h). The speed was a new closed course world record.,             <sup id="cite_ref-8W_15-2" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-8W-15">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 15,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Andretti's final season, in 1994, was dubbed "The Arrivederci Tour."
