He raced in the last of his 407 Indy car races that September.,           </p>,           <h4>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Indianapolis_500">,               Indianapolis 500,             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Indianapolis 500">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h4>,           <div class="thumb tright">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:Mario_and_aldo.jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Mario_and_aldo.jpg/220px-Mario_and_aldo.jpg" width="220" height="142" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Mario_and_aldo.jpg/330px-Mario_and_aldo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Mario_and_aldo.jpg/440px-Mario_and_aldo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1369" data-file-height="884"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Mario_and_aldo.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 , Mario (left) and his brother Aldo (right) at pole day for the ,                 <a href="/wiki/2007_Indianapolis_500" title="2007 Indianapolis 500">,                   2007 Indianapolis 500,                 </a>,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             Andretti won once at the ,             <a href="/wiki/Indianapolis_500" title="Indianapolis 500">,               Indianapolis 500,             </a>,              in 29 attempts. Andretti has had so many incidents and near victories at the track that critics have dubbed the family's performance after Mario's ,             <a href="/wiki/1969_Indianapolis_500" title="1969 Indianapolis 500">,               1969 Indianapolis 500,             </a>,              victory the ",             <a href="/wiki/Andretti_Curse" title="Andretti Curse" class="mw-redirect">,               Andretti Curse,             </a>,             ".,             <sup id="cite_ref-KnightRidder_32-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-KnightRidder-32">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 32,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-33">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 33,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Mario finished all 500 miles (800 km) just five times, including his ,             <a href="/wiki/1969_Indianapolis_500" title="1969 Indianapolis 500">,               1969 Indianapolis 500,             </a>,              victory. Andretti was the first driver to exceed 200 miles per hour (320 km/h) while practicing for the ,             <a href="/wiki/1977_Indianapolis_500" title="1977 Indianapolis 500">,               1977 Indianapolis 500,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-ESPNclassic_34-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-ESPNclassic-34">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 34,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Andretti finished second in the ,             <a href="/wiki/1981_Indianapolis_500" title="1981 Indianapolis 500">,               1981 Indianapolis 500,             </a>,              by eight seconds behind ,             <a href="/wiki/Bobby_Unser" title="Bobby Unser">,               Bobby Unser,             </a>,             . The following day Unser was penalized one lap for passing cars under a caution flag, and Andretti was declared the winner. Unser and his car owner ,             <a href="/wiki/Roger_Penske" title="Roger Penske">,               Roger Penske,             </a>,              appealed the race stewards' decision. USAC overturned the one lap penalty four months later, and penalized Unser with a ,             <a href="/wiki/U.S._dollar" title="U.S. dollar" class="mw-redirect">,               $,             </a>,             40,000 fine.,           </p>,           <p>,             In the ,             <a href="/wiki/1985_Indianapolis_500" title="1985 Indianapolis 500">,               1985 Indianapolis 500,             </a>,             , he was passed by ,             <a href="/wiki/Danny_Sullivan" title="Danny Sullivan">,               Danny Sullivan,             </a>,              in Turn One. A moment later, Sullivan spun in front of Andretti, pitted on his own caution to replace his flat-spotted tires, and then passed Mario again—this time without incident—to go on for the win. Andretti dominated the ,             <a href="/wiki/1987_Indianapolis_500" title="1987 Indianapolis 500">,               1987 Indianapolis 500,             </a>,              testing, led for 170 of the first 177 laps of the race, he had such a big lead that he backed off, but the reduced revs created a harmonic imbalance in his Ilmor/Chevrolet engine that led to a broken valve spring with 20 laps to go.,             <sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-35">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 35,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Andretti suffered broken ankles in the ,             <a href="/wiki/1992_Indianapolis_500" title="1992 Indianapolis 500">,               1992 Indianapolis 500,             </a>,              when he crashed hard in turn four during the race. The ,             <a href="/wiki/1993_Indianapolis_500" title="1993 Indianapolis 500">,               1993 Indianapolis 500,             </a>,              was Andretti's last notable run, and he had just come off a victory at ,             <a href="/wiki/Phoenix_International_Raceway" title="Phoenix International Raceway">,               Phoenix,             </a>,             . On pole day, Andretti was the first car to complete a qualifying run, and sat on the provisional pole position. Mario's speed held up all afternoon, but with less than an hour to go, ,             <a href="/wiki/Arie_Luyendyk" title="Arie Luyendyk">,               Arie Luyendyk,             </a>,              topped his speed, and took the pole. On race day, Mario was a factor most of the afternoon, leading the most laps (72). While leading on lap 134, Mario was penalized for entering the pits while they were closed. A stop-and-go penalty dropped him only down to second place. In the final 50 laps, he began developing handling problems because of his tires, and slid down the standings to finish 5th. Andretti's last race at Indy was the ,             <a href="/wiki/1994_Indianapolis_500" title="1994 Indianapolis 500">,               1994 Indianapolis 500,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-KnightRidder_32-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-KnightRidder-32">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 32,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Aged 63, on April 23, 2003, in the lead up to the 2003 Indy 500, Mario took to the track for the first time in ten years in a major open wheel car. He participated in a test session for son Michael's AGR IndyCar team. One of the team's regular drivers, Tony Kanaan, suffered a radial fracture of his arm on April 15 a crash a week earlier at Motegi. If Kanaan was not cleared to drive in enough time, tentative plans were being prepared for Mario to qualify the car for him. He would turn the car over to Kanaan on race day. No plans had yet been made though for Mario to actually drive in the race. During the test Mario ran at competitive speeds, but running over debris saw his car becoming airborne and the attempt ended with a spectacular crash. Andretti was able to walk away from the wreck. This was Mario's last significant on-track activity at Indianapolis.,           </p>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports_cars">,               Sports cars,             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Sports cars">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h3>,           <div class="thumb tright">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:1989Porsche962MarioAndrettiMichaelAndrettiMillerHighLife.jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/1989Porsche962MarioAndrettiMichaelAndrettiMillerHighLife.jpg/220px-1989Porsche962MarioAndrettiMichaelAndrettiMillerHighLife.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/1989Porsche962MarioAndrettiMichaelAndrettiMillerHighLife.jpg/330px-1989Porsche962MarioAndrettiMichaelAndrettiMillerHighLife.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/1989Porsche962MarioAndrettiMichaelAndrettiMillerHighLife.jpg/440px-1989Porsche962MarioAndrettiMichaelAndrettiMillerHighLife.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2496" data-file-height="1664"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:1989Porsche962MarioAndrettiMichaelAndrettiMillerHighLife.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 , 1989 ,                 <a href="/wiki/Porsche_962" title="Porsche 962">,                   Porsche 962,                 </a>,                  co-driven with son ,                 <a href="/wiki/Michael_Andretti" title="Michael Andretti">,                   Michael,                 </a>,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             Andretti won three 12 Hours of Sebring endurance races (1967, 1970, 1972),,             <sup id="cite_ref-sportscentury_3-13" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-sportscentury-3">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 3,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              and the ,             <a href="/wiki/24_Hours_of_Daytona" title="24 Hours of Daytona">,               24 Hours of Daytona,             </a>,              in 1972. In early sportscar races he competed for the Holman Moody team, but later often drove for Ferrari. He signed with Ferrari in 1971, and won several races with co-driver ,             <a href="/wiki/Jacky_Ickx" title="Jacky Ickx">,               Jacky Ickx,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-FormulaOne.com_16-6" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-FormulaOne.com-16">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 16,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              In 1972 he shared wins in the three North American rounds of the championship and at ,             <a href="/wiki/Brands_Hatch" title="Brands Hatch">,               Brands Hatch,             </a>,              in the UK, contributing to Ferrari's dominant victory in ,             <a href="/wiki/1972_World_Sportscar_Championship_season" title="1972 World Sportscar Championship season">,               that year's World Championship for Makes,             </a>,             . He also competed in the popular North American ,             <a href="/wiki/Can-Am" title="Can-Am">,               Can-Am,             </a>,              series in the late 1960s and early 1970s.,           </p>,           <h4>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Le_Mans">,               Le Mans,             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Le Mans">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h4>,           <p>,             Andretti competed at the ,             <a href="/wiki/24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="24 Hours of Le Mans">,               24 Hours of Le Mans,             </a>,              in four decades. In ,             <a href="/wiki/1966_24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="1966 24 Hours of Le Mans">,               1966,             </a>,              he shared a ,             <a href="/wiki/Holman_Moody" title="Holman Moody">,               Holman Moody,             </a>,             <a href="/wiki/Ford_GT40" title="Ford GT40">,               Ford MKII,             </a>,              with ,             <a href="/wiki/Lucien_Bianchi" title="Lucien Bianchi">,               Lucien Bianchi,             </a>,             . They retired after their car dropped a valve at 10:30 pm,             <sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-36">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 36,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              In ,             <a href="/wiki/1967_24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="1967 24 Hours of Le Mans">,               1967,             </a>,             , during a 3:30 am pit stop, a mechanic inadvertently installed a front brake pad backward on his Ford MkIV. As Andretti passed under the Dunlop Bridge before the Esses, he touched his brake pedal for the first time since leaving the pits. The front wheel instantly locked, turning the car hard into the dirt embankment at 150 mph (240 km/h). The wreckage slid to a stop with Andretti badly shaken, the car sideways to oncoming traffic and the track nearly blocked. His teammates, ,             <a href="/wiki/Jo_Schlesser" title="Jo Schlesser">,               Jo Schlesser,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Roger_McCluskey" title="Roger McCluskey">,               Roger McCluskey,             </a>,             , crashed trying to avoid Andretti's car. McCluskey pulled Andretti to safety, and Andretti was taken to hospital for ,             <a href="/wiki/X-ray" title="X-ray">,               X-rays,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-37">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 37,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-38">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 38,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Andretti did not return to Le Mans until his full-time Formula One career was over. In 1982, he partnered with son Michael in a Mirage M12 Ford. They qualified in ninth place, but the pair found their car being removed from the starting grid 80 minutes before the start of the race,,             <sup id="cite_ref-ian_39-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-ian-39">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 39,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              as an official discovered an oil cooler that was mounted behind the gearbox, which was against the rules. The car had passed initial inspection four days before the race.,             <sup id="cite_ref-ian_39-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-ian-39">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 39,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Despite protests and complaints, the Andretti's entry was removed altogether, replaced by a ,             <a href="/wiki/Porsche_924" title="Porsche 924">,               Porsche 924,             </a>,              Carrera GTR. Their return in the ,             <a href="/wiki/1983_24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="1983 24 Hours of Le Mans">,               following year,             </a>,              was more successful as they finished third. The father/son team returned in ,             <a href="/wiki/1988_24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="1988 24 Hours of Le Mans">,               1988,             </a>,              with Mario's nephew John. They finished sixth in a factory ,             <a href="/wiki/Porsche_962" title="Porsche 962">,               Porsche 962,             </a>,             . Following Mario's retirement from full-time racing, he decided on a return to the circuit to add a Le Mans victory to his achievements. He returned in ,             <a href="/wiki/1995_24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="1995 24 Hours of Le Mans">,               1995,             </a>,              with a second place finish. He said in a 2006 interview that he feels that the ,             <a href="/wiki/Courage_Comp%C3%A9tition" title="Courage Compétition">,               Courage Compétition,             </a>,              team "lost [the 1995] race five times over" through poor organization. He had unsuccessful efforts in the following years with a thirteenth place in ,             <a href="/wiki/1996_24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="1996 24 Hours of Le Mans">,               1996,             </a>,             , and then a DNF (Did Not Finish) for ,             <a href="/wiki/1997_24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="1997 24 Hours of Le Mans">,               1997,             </a>,             . Andretti's final appearance at Le Mans was at the ,             <a href="/wiki/2000_24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="2000 24 Hours of Le Mans">,               2000 race,             </a>,             , six years after his retirement from full-time racing, when he drove the ,             <a href="/wiki/Panoz" title="Panoz" class="mw-redirect">,               Panoz,             </a>,              LMP-1 Roadster-S at the age of 60, finishing 16th.,             <sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-40">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 40,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Awards_and_honors">,               Awards and honors,             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Awards and honors">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h3>,           <p>,             In 2000, the ,             <a href="/wiki/Associated_Press" title="Associated Press">,               Associated Press,             </a>,              and RACER magazine named him Driver of the Century.,             <sup id="cite_ref-CCWScommendatore_41-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-CCWScommendatore-41">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 41,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              He was the Driver of the Year (in the United States) for three years (1967, 1978, and 1984),,             <sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-42">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 42,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              and is the only driver to be Driver of the Year in three decades.,             <sup id="cite_ref-ESPN_12-2" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-ESPN-12">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 12,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Andretti was named the U.S. Driver of the Quarter Century in 1992.,             <sup id="cite_ref-IMHoF_2-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-IMHoF-2">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 2,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              He was inducted into the ,             <a href="/wiki/International_Motorsports_Hall_of_Fame" title="International Motorsports Hall of Fame">,               International Motorsports Hall of Fame,             </a>,              in 2001,,             <sup id="cite_ref-IMHoF_2-2" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-IMHoF-2">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 2,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              the United States ,             <a href="/wiki/National_Sprint_Car_Hall_of_Fame_%26_Museum" title="National Sprint Car Hall of Fame &amp; Museum">,               National Sprint Car Hall of Fame,             </a>,              in 1996,,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-28" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              the ,             <a href="/wiki/Motorsports_Hall_of_Fame_of_America" title="Motorsports Hall of Fame of America">,               Motorsports Hall of Fame of America,             </a>,              in 1990,,             <sup id="cite_ref-mshf_11-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-mshf-11">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 11,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              and the Hoosier Auto Racing Hall of Fame in 1970.,             <sup id="cite_ref-NSCHoF_6-29" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-NSCHoF-6">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 6,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             On October 23, 2006, Andretti was awarded the highest civilian honor given by the Italian government, the ,             <a href="/wiki/Italian_orders_of_merit" title="Italian orders of merit" class="mw-redirect">,               Commendatore dell'Ordine al Merito della Repubblica Italiana,             </a>,              (known as the Commendatore), in honor of his racing career, public service, and enduring commitment to his Italian heritage.,             <sup id="cite_ref-CCWScommendatore_41-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-CCWScommendatore-41">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 41,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <a href="/wiki/Enzo_Ferrari" title="Enzo Ferrari">,               Enzo Ferrari,             </a>,              is the only other recipient of the Commendatore from the world of automobile racing.,           </p>,           <p>,             From 2007 Mario Andretti is the "Mayor" (,             <i>,               Sindaco,             </i>,             ) of the "Free Commune of Motovun in Exile" (,             <i>,               Libero Comune di Montona in esilio,             </i>,             ), an association of Italian exiles from ,             <a href="/wiki/Motovun" title="Motovun">,               Motovun,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-43">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 43,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-44">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 44,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>]]
[ChangeDelta, position: 611, lines: [            <span class="mw-headline" id="Classification">,               Classification] to [            <span class="mw-headline" id="Mario_Andretti_Grand_Prix_of_Road_America">,               Mario Andretti Grand Prix of Road America]]
[ChangeDelta, position: 618, lines: [              <a href="/w/index.php?title=1975_British_Grand_Prix&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Classification">] to [              <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Mario Andretti Grand Prix of Road America">]]
[ChangeDelta, position: 626, lines: [          <table class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%">] to [          <p>,             Mario was instrumental in keeping championship car racing at ,             <a href="/wiki/Road_America" title="Road America">,               Road America,             </a>,             . ,             <a href="/wiki/Champ_Car" title="Champ Car">,               CART,             </a>,              severed its ties with the track as a legal resolution of payment issues from the 2002 and 2003 series ,             <a href="/wiki/Champcar_Grand_Prix_of_Road_America" title="Champcar Grand Prix of Road America" class="mw-redirect">,               events,             </a>,              at the track. Andretti was the middle man between CART President Chris Pook and Road America President George Bruggenthies. After six weeks both sides came to terms and signed a two-year contract. The event was renamed the "Mario Andretti Grand Prix of Road America".,             <sup id="cite_ref-milwaukee_8-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-milwaukee-8">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 8,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <h2>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Elder_of_Andretti_racing_family">,               Elder of Andretti racing family,             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Elder of Andretti racing family">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h2>,           <div class="thumb tright">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:MarioAndrettiAndJohnAndrettiMay2007.jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/MarioAndrettiAndJohnAndrettiMay2007.jpg/220px-MarioAndrettiAndJohnAndrettiMay2007.jpg" width="220" height="157" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/MarioAndrettiAndJohnAndrettiMay2007.jpg/330px-MarioAndrettiAndJohnAndrettiMay2007.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/MarioAndrettiAndJohnAndrettiMay2007.jpg/440px-MarioAndrettiAndJohnAndrettiMay2007.jpg 2x" data-file-width="577" data-file-height="412"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:MarioAndrettiAndJohnAndrettiMay2007.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 , Mario (left) with nephew ,                 <a href="/wiki/John_Andretti" title="John Andretti">,                   John,                 </a>,                  (right) at the ,                 <a href="/wiki/2007_Indianapolis_500" title="2007 Indianapolis 500">,                   2007 Indianapolis 500,                 </a>,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             Both of Mario Andretti's sons, ,             <a href="/wiki/Michael_Andretti" title="Michael Andretti">,               Michael,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Jeff_Andretti" title="Jeff Andretti">,               Jeff,             </a>,             , were auto racers. Michael followed in his father's footsteps by winning the IndyCar title, with Mario's nephew ,             <a href="/wiki/John_Andretti" title="John Andretti">,               John Andretti,             </a>,              joining the series in 1988. This meant that the Andrettis became the first family to have four relatives compete in the same series.,             <sup id="cite_ref-ESPN_12-3" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-ESPN-12">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 12,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              With Mario sharing driving duties with sons Michael and Jeff at the 1991 Rolex 24 at Daytona, driving a Porsche 962, the Andretti clan finished 5th.,             <sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-45">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 45,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Mario's grandson ,             <a href="/wiki/Marco_Andretti" title="Marco Andretti">,               Marco,             </a>,              completed his first full season in the ,             <a href="/wiki/Indy_Racing_League" title="Indy Racing League" class="mw-redirect">,               Indy Racing League,             </a>,              (IRL) in 2006, driving for his father Michael's ,             <a href="/wiki/Andretti_Green_Racing" title="Andretti Green Racing" class="mw-redirect">,               Andretti Green Racing,             </a>,              team. Marco finished second in the ,             <a href="/wiki/2006_Indianapolis_500" title="2006 Indianapolis 500">,               2006 Indianapolis 500,             </a>,              and so became the first third-generation recipient of the race's ,             <a href="/wiki/List_of_Indianapolis_500_Rookies_of_the_Year" title="List of Indianapolis 500 Rookies of the Year" class="mw-redirect">,               Rookie of the Year Award,             </a>,             .,           </p>,           <h2>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Later_life">,               Later life,             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Later life">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h2>,           <p>,             Mario and his wife Dee Ann live near their grandson Marco in mansions in ,             <a href="/wiki/Bushkill_Township,_Pennsylvania" title="Bushkill Township, Pennsylvania" class="mw-redirect">,               Bushkill Township, Pennsylvania,             </a>,             . Dee Ann is a native of Nazareth who taught English to Andretti in 1961.,             <sup id="cite_ref-ESPNclassic_34-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-ESPNclassic-34">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 34,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Dee Ann and Mario were married on November 25, 1961.,             <sup id="cite_ref-Istria_46-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-Istria-46">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 46,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Andretti has kept active after his retirement from full-time racing. He makes numerous speaking engagements before corporate audiences and is a spokesman for longtime sponsors ,             <a href="/wiki/Texaco" title="Texaco">,               Texaco,             </a>,             /,             <a href="/wiki/Havoline" title="Havoline">,               Havoline,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Firestone_Tire_and_Rubber_Company" title="Firestone Tire and Rubber Company">,               Firestone,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Magnaflow_performance_exhaust" title="Magnaflow performance exhaust" class="mw-redirect">,               Magnaflow performance exhaust,             </a>,             . He was occasionally a spokesman for the defunct ,             <a href="/wiki/Champ_Car" title="Champ Car">,               Champ Car World Series,             </a>,             , though he frequently attended IRL races to watch Marco compete. Andretti is ,             <a href="/wiki/Chairman" title="Chairman">,               vice chairman,             </a>,              of a ,             <a href="/wiki/Winery" title="Winery">,               winery,             </a>,              named Andretti Winery in ,             <a href="/wiki/Napa_Valley,_California" title="Napa Valley, California" class="mw-redirect">,               Napa Valley, California,             </a>,             . He owns a chain of gasoline stations, a ,             <a href="/wiki/Toyota" title="Toyota">,               Toyota,             </a>,              dealership in ,             <a href="/wiki/Moon_Township,_Pennsylvania" title="Moon Township, Pennsylvania" class="mw-redirect">,               Moon Township, Pennsylvania,             </a>,              (just outside of ,             <a href="/wiki/Pittsburgh" title="Pittsburgh">,               Pittsburgh,             </a>,             ), car washes, car-care products, ,             <a href="/wiki/Karting" title="Karting" class="mw-redirect">,               go-kart,             </a>,              tracks, a clothing line, video games and replica cars. He also test drives cars for ,             <i>,               <a href="/wiki/Road_%26_Track" title="Road &amp; Track">,                 Road &amp; Track,               </a>,             </i>,              and ,             <i>,               <a href="/wiki/Car_and_Driver" title="Car and Driver">,                 Car and Driver,               </a>,             </i>,              magazines.,             <sup id="cite_ref-C16_5-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-C16-5">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 5,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             In July 2006 Mario took part in the Bullrun race across America.,             <sup id="cite_ref-C16_5-2" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-C16-5">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 5,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The first pitstop was at the ,             <a href="/wiki/Pocono_Raceway" title="Pocono Raceway">,               Pocono Raceway,             </a>,              (in Andretti's state of Pennsylvania), with Gate No. 5 aptly named Andretti Road.,           </p>,           <h2>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Media_appearances">,               Media appearances,             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Media appearances">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h2>,           <p>,             Andretti played himself on three episodes of the United States television show ,             <i>,               <a href="/wiki/Home_Improvement_(TV_series)" title="Home Improvement (TV series)">,                 Home Improvement,               </a>,             </i>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-InternetMovieDatabase_47-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-InternetMovieDatabase-47">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 47,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              and also appears in films such as the ,             <a href="/wiki/IMAX" title="IMAX">,               IMAX,             </a>,              movie ,             <i>,               <a href="/wiki/Super_Speedway" title="Super Speedway">,                 Super Speedway,               </a>,             </i>,              about the making of ,             <a href="/wiki/Newman/Haas_Racing" title="Newman/Haas Racing">,               Newman/Haas Racing,             </a>,              cars as well as being about Mario Andretti and Michael Andretti.,             <sup id="cite_ref-InternetMovieDatabase_47-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-InternetMovieDatabase-47">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 47,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Mario is also in the ,             <a href="/wiki/Pixar" title="Pixar">,               Pixar,             </a>,              Animation Studios film ,             <i>,               <a href="/wiki/Cars_(film)" title="Cars (film)">,                 Cars,               </a>,             </i>,             ,,             <sup id="cite_ref-InternetMovieDatabase_47-2" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-InternetMovieDatabase-47">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 47,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              where his voice is used for a cameo in which he plays the 1967 ,             <a href="/wiki/Ford_Fairlane_(Americas)" title="Ford Fairlane (Americas)">,               Ford Fairlane,             </a>,              in which he won the ,             <a href="/wiki/Daytona_500" title="Daytona 500">,               Daytona 500,             </a>,             , a parody of his own success in that race. Mario appeared in the ,             <a href="/wiki/Off-road_racing" title="Off-road racing">,               off-road racing,             </a>,              documentary ,             <i>,               <a href="/wiki/Dust_to_Glory" title="Dust to Glory">,                 Dust to Glory,               </a>,             </i>,              as the race Grand Marshall, where the movie documents the 2004 ,             <a href="/wiki/Baja_1000" title="Baja 1000">,               Baja 1000,             </a>,              race.,             <sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-48">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 48,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Mario also wrote a racing column for the ,             <a href="/wiki/Indianapolis_Star" title="Indianapolis Star" class="mw-redirect">,               Indianapolis Star,             </a>,              where he wrote about other drivers, equipment and cars.,             <sup id="cite_ref-Istria_46-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-Istria-46">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 46,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Mario Andretti was featured in the 2007 documentary ,             <i>,               <a href="/wiki/A_State_of_Vine_(film)" title="A State of Vine (film)" class="mw-redirect">,                 A State of Vine,               </a>,             </i>,             , where he commented on his winemaking activities. He has a voice part in the movie ,             <i>,               <a href="/wiki/Turbo_(film)" title="Turbo (film)">,                 Turbo,               </a>,             </i>,             .,           </p>,           <h2>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Racing_career_results">,               Racing career results,             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Racing career results">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h2>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Complete_24_Hours_of_Le_Mans_results">,               Complete 24 Hours of Le Mans results,             </span>,             <span class="mw-editsection">,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 [,               </span>,               <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Andretti&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Complete 24 Hours of Le Mans results">,                 edit,               </a>,               <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">,                 ],               </span>,             </span>,           </h3>,           <table class="wikitable">]]
